did.abstract: One piece of paper showing the land holdings of Jeremiah Brown in Ontario County, New York, 1828.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Jeremiah Brown apparently lived part of his life across the town line in Wayne County, and was a prominent Freemason there. It is clear that Brown was a substantial landowner, for the inventory slip preserved here shows that he left 14 2/5 lots (each presumably hundreds of acres) to his heirs. A careful comparison of the lot numbers listed shows that Brown held land scattered throughout the town, including the land immediately adjacent to the Joseph Smith farm (where the future founder of Mormonism would live on Manchester Lot No. 1 with his family and claim his first visionary experiences in the 1820s).

scopecontent.p: Piece of paper, 3 x 8 inches, that says, Number of lots belonging to Jeremiah Brown’s Heirs in township of No 11. 3d range of townships in Phelps Gorham purchase in Ontario County, state of New York now called Farmington, and listing lot numbers. On the back it says, Allen Brown Sent. From 1800s. Also a photocopied map, 11 x 16.5 inches, showing location of Smith home site in Manchester, New York, 1828.

odd.p: This unimpressive looking little piece of paper may be the only record that remains of the land left by one of the original dozen men who made the first purchase of property in the Phelps and Gorham Purchase. Enclosed is a photocopy of the relevant area from the 1929 Burr map of Ontario County, on which the lot numbers are indicated, making it possible to spot the precise properties listed on this original document.
